content.text: Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1
• The distance between the end of the rule and the loop of string attached to the spring is \(25.0 \text{cm}\). **Keep this distance constant throughout the experiment.**
The distance between the end of the rule and the loop of string supporting the mass hanger is \(x\)
The distance between the end of the rule and the loop of string attached to stand B is \(y\)
Adjust the apparatus until \(x = 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(y = 75.0 \text{cm}\)
• The strings and spring should be vertical and the rule should be parallel to the bench
The length of the coiled section of the spring is \(v.\) To view this more clearly, you may use the adhesive putty to attach the white card to stand A behind the spring
Measure and record \(v.\)
Change \(x\) by moving the loop of string supporting the mass hanger to a different position on the rule
• Move stand B and slide the loop of string attached to stand B along the rule until \(\mathbf{v}\) has **the same value as in (a)**
• Ensure the strings and spring are vertical and the rule is parallel to the bench
• Measure and record \(x\) and \(y\)
x =
y =
Write down your value of \(v\) from (a)
v =
• Repeat (b) until you have six sets of values of \(x\) and \(y\). Record your results in a table
Plot a graph of \(y\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =

In this experiment, you will investigate the forces acting on a metre rule
You have been provided with two lids and some coins
• Take the larger of the two lids
• The diameter of the lid is \(d.\) The height of the lid is \(t,\) as shown in Fig. 2.1
Measure and record \(d\) and \(t\)
d =
t =
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(d\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........
The volume of the air space within the lid is \(V.\)
Calculate \(V\) where
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of \(V.\)
Place the lid on the surface of the water so that it floats with its open face upwards
• Add coins to the inside of the lid. After you have added \(n\) coins, the lid will sink
• Record \(n.\)
Take the **smaller** lid and repeat **(a)**(i), **(b)**(i) and **(c)**
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)

second value of \(k =\)

where the density \(\rho\) of water is \(1.00 \text{g} \text{cm}^{-3}\) and \(M\) is the mass of a coin
Using your second value of \(k\), calculate \(M\). Give an appropriate unit
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**
In this experiment, you will investigate the upthrust on lids placed in water
